etymologies: late 16th century (in the sense ‘dignified, aloof’): from Latin sublimis, from sub- ‘up to’ + a second element perhaps related to limen ‘threshold’, limus ‘oblique’

definitions: of very great excellence or beauty

examples.text: experiences that ranged from the sublime to the ridiculous

shortDefinitions: of very great excellence or beauty

definitions: producing an overwhelming sense of awe or other high emotion through being vast or grand
shortDefinitions: producing overwhelming sense of awe or other high emotion through being vast or grand

definitions: (of a person's attitude or behaviour) extreme or unparalleled

examples.text: he had the sublime confidence of youth

shortDefinitions: (of person's attitude or behaviour) extreme or unparalleled

definitions: (of a solid substance) change directly into vapour when heated, typically forming a solid deposit again on cooling

examples.text: the ice sublimed away, leaving the books dry and undamaged

shortDefinitions: (of solid substance) change directly into vapour when heated

examples.text: these crystals could be sublimed under a vacuum

definitions: elevate to a high degree of moral or spiritual purity or excellence

examples.text: let your thoughts be sublimed by the spirit of God

shortDefinitions: elevate to high degree of moral or spiritual purity or excellence
